A0 Grammar lessons and exercises

1. The present simple of the verb be has three forms:
• I am.
• He/She/It is.
• You/We/They are.

3. We use he for a man, she for a woman, and it for a thing: 
• He’s strong. 
• She’s beautiful. 
• I like this car. It’s very fast.
4. We use they for people and for things: \n• I love Christy and Jonas. They’re my friends. \n• I love these cars. They are very beautiful.

5. We use ‘m, ‘s and ‘re with personal pronouns (I, you, he, she, etc.): 
• I’m tired. 
• You’re funny. 
• She’s from America. 
 But we can use ‘s with names: 
• Jessica’s beautiful. 
• London’s an expensive city. 
• Mark’s clever.
6. We always need a subject before the verb: \n• It is hot (NOT Is hot) \n• Nevera is a fast car (NOT is a fast car)

7. We can only use contractions in negative short answer. Not in positive short answers: 
• Yes, I am (NOT Yes, I’m) 
• Yes, you are (NOT Yes, you’re) 
• Yes, he is (NOT Yes, he’s) 
• Yes, she is (NOT Yes, she’s) 
• Yes, we are (NOT Yes, we’re) 
• Yes, they are ( Not Yes, they’re)

1. We use this and these for things that are here(near). This is singular and these is plural:\n This is my new watch.\n These are my cars.
2. We use that and those for things that are there(not near). That is singular and those is plural:\nThat man is very fast.\n I need those boxes over there.

3. We can use this, that, these, those with a noun(this box, that car, etc.) or without a noun:
This watch is very expensive.
I like that woman in the park.
Who is that?(=that person).
4. We use this is when we introduce people and on the telephone:\nHi this is Tim(Tim on the telephone).
1. We use subject pronouns + verb and we use possessive adjectives + noun:\nThese are Cris and Margaret, they are from London.\nI love my car.
2. Adjectives in English have no plural form. Possessive adjectives are always singular:\nThese are ttheir suitcases. (NOT theirs suitcases)

3. We use he-his and she-her for people, and we use it-its for things. But in the plural, we use they-their for people and things:\nI like those cars, they are beautiful. But their technology is outdated.
4. We use hit’s(=hit is) to talk about the time or the weather:\nhIt’s very cold today, but hit’s sunny.\n‘What time his it?’ ‘hIt’s three o’clock.
5. Its = possessive adjective. It’s = it is (subject + verb be):\nLook at that corgi. It’s beautiful.\n I like its ears.
1. We use a/an with singular nouns:\nThis is a car.\nIt’s an apple.
2. We use a with nouns beginning with a consonant, and we use an with nouns beggining with a vovel(a, e, i, o, u):\nGive me an orange.\nIt’s an amazing experience.

3. We also use an with nouns beginning with h it the h is not pronounced. But we use a if the h is pronounced:\nGive me an hour(The h is not pronounced in hour).\nI want wear a hat(The h> is pronounced in hat).
4. We use a and NOT an with nouns beginning with u when it pronounced [ju:], like university:\nI wear a uniform.
5. We do not use a/an with plural nouns:\nThese are cars(NOT a cars).
6. We add -s to make plural nouns in English. Some times we need to add -es, -ies or -ves. Check the spelling in the table.
7. Some words have irregular plurals and do NOT add -s to make their plural form.
